_exec_summary.SummaryText:
ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

Ammonia is the only hazardous chemical used at this facility that is subject to the CalARP program or federal RMP requirements.

This facility recognizes the hazards associated with the use of highly hazardous chemicals.  As a reflection of our policy to adhere to all applicable federal, state, and local laws and regulations, we submit this plan to address the hazards inherent with the use of ammonia.  Our program addresses safety precautions regarding the handling and operation of this covered system as well as proper training for those who operate and maintain the system.  The company training policy requires that all employees will be properly trained for a job position before assignment to that job.

Our accidental release prevention program is clearly defined by the OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) Program for this facility.  This prevention program follows industry-recommended standards for preventing unnecessary human exposures and reducing the threat to the health of our employees as well as to members of the community and the surrounding area.  Safety depends upon the manner in which we handle these chemicals, the safety devices inherent in the design of this facility and its processes, and the training that we provide our personnel.  This Plan is updated as required by law.

Our Emergency Action Plan (EAP) details the actions this facility will take in the event of an emergency.  The Plan includes procedures for notification of the local emergency responders and safe evacuation of personnel on-site.  A primary Emergency Coordinator (EC) has been assigned to implement the required actions and a secondary Emergency Coordinator has been assigned as a backup to the primary EC.  This Plan is current and updated as required by law and conforms to the requirements for an Emergency Action Plan as per 29 CFR 1910.38 and 8 CCR 3220.

This facility has also coordinated with the local emergency respond

ers and will maintain close contact to ensure that the responders are familiar with the system and with the general safety and accidental release program at our plant.

It is the policy of this facility to devote the time, energy, and capital toward maintaining prevention and response programs appropriate to the inherent dangers with the use of hazardous chemicals.

 
THE STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED

The Stationary Source

The WinCo Foods facility is located in the agriculturally productive Central Valley in Modesto, California.  The plant is situated at about 90 feet above sea level at the southern border of the city limits of Modesto along Crows Landing Road, south of Service Road.  

WinCo Foods operates this facility as a food distribution center for its retail outlets.  The facility was built in 2004 and the ammonia refrigeration system began operation in April 2004.  WinCo Foods uses anhydrous ammonia for maintaining refrigerated and frozen food products.  The products stored are required to be kept frozen or chilled until placed in refrigerated trucks for delivery to retail and wholesale outlets.

Plant security is provided by a guard located at the truck gate entrance to the facility and by Main Office personnel at the front desk. The security guard provides emergency response support under the direction of the Emergency Coordinator.  The entire plant is enclosed by a chain-link fence, except at the Main Office entrance.

Regulated Substance Handled

PROCESS DESCRIPTION

This food distribution facility operates a multi-temperature, anhydrous ammonia (R-717) refrigeration system with an engine room capacities of 366 TR @ +35°F high temperature suction, 671 TR @ +12°F medium temperature suction, and 210 TR @ -24°F low temperature suction.  The total system charge of anhydrous ammonia is approximately 35,000 lbs.

SYSTEM CLASSIFICATION

This refrigeration system is a liquid recirculation system and is designed to operate with an overfeed-

ratio of approximately 3:1 for evaporative air units.  Anhydrous ammonia (R-717) refrigerant is an IMC Class B2 refrigerant.  Rotary screw compressors are used in the refrigeration system.  Engine room electrical classification is non-hazardous due to the ventilation system for continuous and emergency purging.

SYSTEM TEMPERATURES

This ammonia refrigeration system contains eight interconnected subsystems:

1. Low-temperature recirculation evaporator system (-24°F @ 1.7 psig).
2. Medium-temperature evaporator system (+12°F @ 25.6 psig).
3. High-temperature evaporator system (+35°F @ 51.6 psig).
4. Thermosiphon pilot receiver system (95°F @ 181 psig).
5. Condenser system (95°F C.T. 71°F W.B.).
6. Compressor low-temperature system (-24°F @ 1.7 psig).
7. Compressor medium-temperature system (+12°F @ 25.6 psig).
8. Compressor high-temperature system (+35°F @ 51.6 psig).

SYSTEM STAGES

This system operates in part as a single-stage system and also a two-stage compression system.  Thirty-two (32) evaporative air-units operate at a +35 °F suction temperature.  Forty-two (42) evaporative air-units operate at a +12 °F suction temperature using the two-stage intercooler as a recirculator vessel.  Eighteen (18) evaporative air-units operate at a -24 °F suction temperature.

ENGINE ROOM

Major equipment located inside the engine room includes:

1. Two Low Temperature Booster (Low Temperature) Compressors (Two (2) M&M model A65BT Screw Compressors each @ 104.9 TR).
2. Two High Temperature Compressors (One (1) M&M model A45HT Screw Compressor @ 215.7 TR and One (1) M&M model A30HT Screw Compressor @ 150.1 TR).
3. Three Medium Temperature Compressors (Two (2) M&M model A113HT Screw Compressors each @ 333 TR and One (1) M&M model A87HT Screw Compressor @ 257.3 TR). 
4. One 36¿ dia. x 11¿-9¿ OAL thermosiphon Pilot Receiver @ +95°F.
5. One 96¿ dia. x 18¿-0¿ OAH Controlled-Pressure Receiver @ +47°F.
6. One 48 dia. x 12'-4 OAH Vertical Recirculator Package @ +35°F.
7. One 84 dia.

x 16'-0 OAH Intercooler & Vertical Recirculator Package @ +12°F.
8. One 60 dia. x 12'-9 OAH Vertical Recirculator Package @ -24°F.
9. One-Hansen APC Auto-Purger.

OUTSIDE ENGINE ROOM

Major equipment located outside on the roof includes:

Two (2) Evaporative Condensers (both EVAPCO model PMCB-855 condensers, rated @ 14,404 MBH at standard conditions).

LOW TEMPERATURE RECIRCULATOR PACKAGE

The low-temperature recirculator is a vertical pressure vessel.  The volume of this vessel at maximum allowable liquid level (80% of total vessel volume) is 181.6 cu. Ft.  It operates at a saturated liquid temperature of -24°F.  The low-temperature liquid is pumped from this vessel to the freezer air units where thirty percent of the liquid mass is evaporated.  The liquid-vapor mixture is returned to this vessel where the liquid is separated from the vapor.  The low temperature compressors take the ammonia vapor from this vessel and compress it to approximately 25.6 psig.  This vessel has connection with the low temperature compressors (dry suction) and with the low-temperature evaporators (wet suction and pumped liquid).

INTERCOOLER

The intercooler is a vertical pressure vessel.  The volume of this vessel at maximum allowable liquid level (80% of total vessel volume) is 444.0 cu. Ft.  It operates at a saturated liquid temperature of +12°F.  The low-stage booster compressors discharge superheated vapor into this vessel.  The superheated vapor bubbles up through liquid ammonia giving up its superheat and creating more vapor volume.  Liquid ammonia for the low-temperature loads is fed into this vessel and is cooled to saturation temperature.  The medium-temperature liquid is pumped from this vessel to the medium-temperature air units where thirty percent of the liquid mass is evaporated.  The liquid-vapor mixture is returned to this vessel where the liquid is separated from the vapor.  The high-stage compressors pull ammonia vapor from this vessel and compress it to approximate

ly 181 psig.  This vessel has connection with low-stage booster compressors, high-stage compressors, medium-temperature air units, and with the high-pressure liquid piping.

HIGH TEMPERATURE RECIRCULATOR PACKAGE

The high-temperature recirculator is a vertical pressure vessel.  The volume of this vessel at maximum allowable liquid level (80% of total vessel volume) is 113.8 cu. Ft.  It operates a saturated liquid temperature of +35°F.  The high-temperature liquid is pumped from this vessel to the cooler air units where thirty- percent of the liquid mass is evaporated.  The liquid-vapor mixture is returned to this vessel where the liquid is separated from the vapor. The high-temperature compressors take the ammonia vapor from this vessel and compress it to approximately 181 psig.  This vessel has connection with the high-temperature compressors (dry suction) and with the high-temperature evaporators (wet suction and pumped liquid).

CONTROLLED-PRESSURE RECEIVER

The controlled-pressure receiver is a vertical pressure vessel.  The volume of this vessel at maximum allowable liquid level (80% of total vessel volume) is 655.5 cu. Ft. at saturated liquid temperature of +47°F.  The controlled-pressure receiver stores the ammonia liquid from the condenser.  The liquid enters the top of the vessel from the thermosiphon pilot receiver and is maintained at 70 psig by a pressure regulator.  This vessel has connection with the thermosiphon pilot receiver, and the recirculator vessels.

THERMOSIPHON PILOT RECEIVER

The thermosiphon pilot receiver is a horizontal high-pressure vessel.  It is sized and used for storing a minimum five-minute supply of liquid ammonia for oil cooling and for separating liquid out of the return flow of ammonia from the thermosiphon oil coolers.  The liquid volume in this vessel at normal operating level (50% of total vessel volume) is 25.3 cu. Ft. at a saturated liquid temperature of +95°F.  All liquid from the condenser flows through this vessel.  The

thermosiphon oil coolers on the screw compressors are fed from this vessel and return a liquid-vapor mix back through the thermosiphon return piping.  Most of the liquid ammonia from the condenser drains through this receiver to the high temperature recirculator.

CONDENSERS

The evaporative condensers use axial fans in a draw-through configuration.  High-pressure ammonia vapor flows from the high-stage compressors to the evaporative condenser where heat is removed.  The vapor is condensed into a high-pressure liquid using air and water flowing over the outside of the condensing pipe coils.  High-pressure liquid from the condenser is drained to the thermosiphon pilot receiver and overflows to the controlled-pressure receiver.  The saturated condensing temperature is 95°F (181 psig) at a corresponding 71°F WB.  The condenser has connections with the compressor discharge lines, the thermosiphon pilot receiver, and the purger.

PURGER

This system incorporates an automatic gas purger for removing non-condensable gases from the ammonia system.  The presence of non-condensable gases in the condenser penalizes the system performance through the artificial elevation of condensing pressure.  The non-condensable gases add their partial pressures to the ammonia partial pressure against which the compressors must pump.  The system has several purge point connections, typically at each of the condenser liquid outlet pipes. 

HOT GAS DEFROST

The compressor discharge hot gas is used to defrost the evaporators.  During defrost, the hot gas refrigerant gives up heat and condenses.  With the fans shut down, the ability of the coil to transfer that heat to the air is severely limited.  Thus, the heat from the hot gas is absorbed by metal in the coil.  As the metal absorbs heat, its temperature rises.  Once the surface temperature is high enough, any ice and/or frost on the coil surface will melt and drain off.  Defrosting the evaporators occurs automatically on a time sequence, by

individual sequence timers.

EVAPORATORS FOR ROOM CONDITIONING

The evaporators are fed from liquid pumps on the recirculator packages.  The feed rate is approximately 3:1.  This efficiency of this system is increased by circulating up to three times the amount of the refrigerant needed by the evaporator for the rated capacity.  This system operates in part as a single-stage system and also as a two-stage compression system.

AMMONIA PIPING AND VALVES

The ammonia piping and valves in the system are labeled.  The identification system is recognized by IIAR.  P&ID prints are available for review.  Pipe, fittings, and connections specifications for ammonia refrigeration systems shall meet or exceed ASME/ANSI B31.5 specifications.

THE GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND THE CHEMICAL SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

This facility complies with the California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program, the federal Accidental Release Prevention Program and OSHA¿s Process Safety Management (PSM) Program.  Key prevention steps taken by this facility to maintain safety are outlined in the PSM Program.  These include the description of all system and equipment information, process hazard analysis, operator training, contractor qualification, operating procedures, pre-startup safety review, hot work permitting, management of change, mechanical integrity, incident investigation, compliance audits, and emergency response.

Those who operate, maintain, or supervise the system are trained to understand the principles of ammonia refrigeration and ammonia properties, an understanding of the process equipment and proper operating and maintenance procedures, recognition of abnormal conditions and the steps to correct deviations, and emergency shutdown procedures as appropriate to the level of involvement each employee or contractor will have with the process.  Contractors that perform maintenance or that design changes to the system are qualified by the facility based upo

n their experience and safety record before being selected to provide such services.

The general safety program includes hazardous communication, forklift operation, first aid, emergency response, and additional programs as necessary to maintain a safe operation.

THE FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

There have been no accidental releases of ammonia at this facility in the last five (5) years that resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage on site, or known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering-in-place, property damage, or environmental damage.

THE EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

Employees are trained to understand the requirements of the Emergency Action Plan.  The Emergency Action Plan includes release notification for emergency responders and the procedures for evacuation.  The Emergency Coordinator implements the response in coordination with the local emergency responders (i.e. the fire department).  It is the policy and practice to conduct evacuation drills regularly.

This facility is included in the community emergency response plan.  The Primary Local Emergency Response Agency with which the response activities are coordinated is:

Local Emergency Planning Committee
Region IV
3650 Schriever Avenue
Mather CA  95655
916-845-8480

In addition to the PSM/ARP requirements, this facility is also subject to RCRA regulations at 40 CFR 264, 265, and 279.52; Emergency Action Plan requirements under 40 CFR 1910.38 and 8 CCR 3220; and, state EPCRA rules and laws.

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

An update Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) was performed as required prior to implementation of the major changes for the 2008 freezer expansion project.  The five-year revalidation of the PHA was completed concurrently approximately six months prior to the anniversary date to secure cost and time efficiencies.  The 2008 PHA team developed a list of recommendations to improve safety by reducing potential hazards of the process.  All recommendations have

been scheduled for completion and implementation responsibility has been assigned for each action item (see PHA Update and Revalidation Report dated November 15, 2008).

Representative planned changes to improve safety include:

	  Review of valve accessibility for maintenance and emergencies
	  Replacement of pressure relief valves
	  Review of requirements for updated seismic assessment
	  Revised Standard Operating Procedures
